      java.lang.String getToolHome()
      This method will firstly try to return the field toolHome
      If it is null, it will try to get the toolHome from properties getToolHomeProperties()
      If still not found, it will try to get the toolHome from environments getToolHomeEnvs()
      If still not found, it will throw out IllegalStateException.
      If the toolHome if found, it will be set to field toolHome.
      protected java.util.List<java.lang.String> getToolHomeEnvs()
      Subclass should override this method to provide its own environment variables.

      Subclass should override this method to provide its own system properties.

      void setToolHome(java.lang.String toolHome)
      Only you are sure about the tool's home, you can set it.
      Because if you set it, getToolHome() will not try to get the tool's home
      from "JVM properties" or "System environment variables"
      This method will verify if the toolHome exists and is a directory.

      • locateTool

        protected java.lang.String locateTool(java.lang.String tool)
        Try to find the location of the executable tools in the sdk's home path. It will try to look the tool in some sub directories, such as bin, tools If still not found, throw the IllegalStateException.
        Parameters:
        tool - name like "adb.exe", "batch.bat" or "script.sh" etc...
        Returns:
        String absolute path to the tool or throws the exception
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if tool cannot be found.

      • searchFile

        protected java.lang.String searchFile(java.io.File directory,
                                      java.lang.String filename,
                                      boolean recusive)
        Try to find a file matching 'filename' within directory.
        Parameters:
        directory - File, the directory in which to search file
        filename - String, the filename to match
        recusive - boolean, if we need to search files in sub-directories
        Returns:
        String, the absolute filename or null if not found.
        See Also:
        locateTool(String)

      • needSearchRecursively

        protected boolean needSearchRecursively(java.lang.String directoryName)
        Parameters:
        directoryName - String, the directory to be searched
        Returns:
        boolean, true if we need to search in the sub-directories
        See Also:
        locateTool(String)

      • setToolHome

        public void setToolHome(java.lang.String toolHome)
        Only you are sure about the tool's home, you can set it.
        Because if you set it, getToolHome() will not try to get the tool's home
        from "JVM properties" or "System environment variables"
        This method will verify if the toolHome exists and is a directory. If not, it will
        throw out IllegalStateException.
        Parameters:
        toolHome -
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException
        See Also:
        getToolHome()

      • getToolHome

        public java.lang.String getToolHome()
        This method will firstly try to return the field toolHome
        If it is null, it will try to get the toolHome from properties getToolHomeProperties()
        If still not found, it will try to get the toolHome from environments getToolHomeEnvs()
        If still not found, it will throw out IllegalStateException.
        If the toolHome if found, it will be set to field toolHome.
        Returns:
        The tool home where (or sub-directory) the tools' executable can be found.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException
        See Also:
        setToolHome(String)

      • getToolHomeProperties

        protected java.util.List<java.lang.String> getToolHomeProperties()
        Subclass should override this method to provide its own system properties.
        Returns:
        A list of 'system property name', where the 'tool home' may be stored.

      • getToolHomeEnvs

        protected java.util.List<java.lang.String> getToolHomeEnvs()
        Subclass should override this method to provide its own environment variables.
        Returns:
        A list of 'environment variable name', where the 'tool home' may be stored.

        public java.lang.String getLastCommand()

        Parameters:

        args, - String, the parameters of the executable.

        Throws:
